text: do we care if the brackets are steel or aluminum? If steel and we were bending them ourselves (vs welding up channel, angle, and bar) they would be a max of 0.065" thick or 1/16"
aluminum could be thicker, maybe 0.08 or 0.09" or something
if welding we could use 1/8" wall shapes for each
these are for the table brackets
we can also use 1/16" in welding (TIG)
as long as material stresses allow it
ooh, can I do some Finite Element Analysis? I haven't had a real application for that skill since learning it in school

I'm exploring options for FEA/FEM software. I'd be happiest with Solidworks (which ADX has. pretty sure they have the right packages for it), but for in-house software I'm doing an audit of current, OS X, free options.
In the near-term, this will let me evaluate different proposals for the new desk brackets.
in the long term, we can use this tool in the RPD pipeline.
err oops, were those finish washers supposed to go in space planning... my bad
Assuming I don't find any satisfactory free programs (which, if I'm pessimistic, I do assume), I'll start on whatever "free trial" programs I can find.
I would be interested in some tutoring in CAD/CAM in general and FEA stuff in particular
once you figure out a good tool or tools
in a perfect world we'd have 1 or 2 dedicated machines with Solidworks Premium and (2) 27" monitors (each). But that's only if we have ~18k burning a hole in our pocket.

text: the reclaimed bowling alley wood is not a requirement
what are you thinking its for? for the conference rooms?
on a scale of trivial (1) to impossible (11), it's probably a 3
no i am thinking in lieu of a kitchen island. was talking to marce about it... ikea kitchen islands need to be attached to the floor
there are some things that could make it easier (such as if we had huge stock like a reclaimed bowling alley)
If we were doing large-scale glue-ups then it could get a little more complicated
but that really only adds time
k, just curious :simple_smile:
I have a finger jointing jig in seattle for use on a crosscut sled
may or may not hekp
help
i've seen a box joint jig at ADX too
(box=finger)
though unless a box/finger joint is actually part of the design direction, it would be easier to use something else, like biscuits and registration pins
joints dont nec. need to be like that - just like the simple shape: <http://noxo.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/freestanding-kitchen-island-with-seating-freestanding-kitchen-island-220x200.jpg>
is it a priority for this to be disassembled at all?
it should be something that can be brought into/out of the office
and by that i mean, if we were ever to move offices, we could take it with us, as opposed to building it in here and having it be stuck here
sure. but as long as it can get into and out of the building, there's little need for it to collapse further?
I'd just make sure it could go through a 36" door
are our doorways that wide?
probably 33
Ikea sells large butcher block countertops that you could use to build a table like that
iirc you need to show up when the doors open in order to get those
but certainly doable
or go to Aurora Mills Salvage and get a set of bleachers
I would look at salvage places first (rebuliding center, salvageworks, ...)
I built a booth for my sister down in menlo park out of ikea butcherblock stuff and oak plywood
